The Inverse Exponential distribution

Source: R/dist_inverse_exponential.R
dist_inverse_exponential.Rd

dist_inverse_exponential(rate)

Arguments

rate

an alternative way to specify the scale.

See also

actuar::InverseExponential

Examples

dist <- dist_inverse_exponential(rate = 1:5)
dist
#> <distribution[5]>
#> [1] InvExp(1) InvExp(2) InvExp(3) InvExp(4) InvExp(5)

mean(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
variance(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
support(dist)
#> <support_region[5]>
#> [1] (0,Inf) (0,Inf) (0,Inf) (0,Inf) (0,Inf)
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1]  3.8209414  0.4702427  0.6345856  1.2315965 66.9750594  3.1905763
#>  [7]  1.7292098  2.3941126  0.4732766 44.2034126
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1] 0.2507873 0.7958854 1.6256982 0.4520162 2.5881285 1.0979148 3.1322792
#>  [8] 0.6768017 0.2263615 5.8904361
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1]  0.1566610  1.7223379  0.1122997  3.0800107 21.0901320  0.3200861
#>  [7]  0.2198967  0.3020957  0.2566221  7.7998641
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1] 0.6964321 0.2073317 1.4145016 0.3576624 0.3990666 0.8706276 0.1144461
#>  [8] 0.5465287 0.7262746 0.3908681
#> 
#> [[5]]
#>  [1] 0.58648786 0.68060245 0.25637734 0.30597252 0.83767352 0.29320895
#>  [7] 0.16852528 0.09554215 0.26513364 0.14072039
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 0.15163266 0.09735010 0.07054014 0.05515606 0.04524187
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -1.886294 -2.329442 -2.651573 -2.897589 -3.095732

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.7788008 0.8824969 0.9200444 0.9394131 0.9512294

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 2.8036733 1.4018366 0.9345578 0.7009183 0.5607347
